{{also|Foo|fo'o|foo'}} ==English== ===Pronunciation=== * {{a|UK}} {{IPA|en|/fuː/}} * {{audio|en|En-au-foo.ogg|Audio (AU)}} * {{rhymes|en|uː}} * {{homophones|en|-fu}} ===Etymology 1=== From {{der|en|cmn|府|tr=fǔ}}. ====Noun==== {{en-noun}} # {{lb|en|historical|obsolete}} {{alt form|en|fu|nodot=a}}: an [[administrative]] [[subdivision]] of [[imperial]] [[China]]; the [[capital]] of [[such]] [[division]]s. ===Etymology 2=== [[File:Chinese Good Fortune Cross Stitch Pattern.JPG|thumb|upright|'''foo''' is presumably based on the {{w|fu character}} (fú, 福)]] From {{der|en|zh|福||[[fortunate]]; [[prosperity]], [[good]] [[luck]]|tr=fú}}, via its use as {{m|zh|福星||[[Jupiter]]|tr=Fúxīng}} in Chinese statues of the [[w:Sanxing (deities)|Three Lucky Stars]], picked up from c. 1935 as a nonsense word in [[w:Bill Holman|Bill Holman]]'s ''[[w:Smokey Stover|Smokey Stover]]'' comic strip,“[http://catb.org/jargon/html/F/foo.html foo]”, ''[http://catb.org/jargon/html/index.html The Jargon File]''"[http://www.smokey-stover.com/history.html The History of Bill Holman]", [http://www.smokey-stover.com/ Smokey-Stover.com], Smokey Stover LLC – article by nephew of Bill Holman"[https://web.archive.org/web/19990222143614/http://members.aol.com/EOCostello/ Warner Brothers Cartoon Companion]" whence it was picked up by ''[[w:w:Pogo (comic strip)|Pogo]]'', ''[[w:The Daffy Doc|Looney Tunes]]'', and others. Used by [[w:Jack Speer|Jack Speer]] as the [[fannish]] [[ghod]] of [[mimeography]]. Popularized in computing contexts by the [[w:Tech Model Railroad Club|Tech Model Railroad Club]]'s 1959 ''Dictionary of the TMRC Language'', which incorporated it into a parody of the Hindu chant {{m|en|om mani padme hum}}, possibly under the influence of WWII military slang {{m|en|fubar}}, which had been repopularized by [[w:Joseph Heller|Joseph Heller]]'s ''[[w:Catch-22|Catch-22]]''. {{wikipedia}} ====Noun==== {{en-noun|-}} # {{lb|en|programming}} A [[metasyntactic variable]] used to represent an [[unspecified]] entity. If part of a series of such entities, it is often the first in the series, and followed immediately by [[bar]]. #: {{ux|en|Suppose we have two objects, '''foo''' and bar.}} # {{lb|en|fandom slang}} {{alternative case form of|en|Foo|gloss=placeholder god}} =====Derived terms===== * {{l|en|foobar}} =====Related terms===== * {{l|en|FUBAR}} ===Etymology 3=== A [[minced oath|minced]] form of {{m|en|fuck}}. ====Interjection==== {{en-interj}} # {{non-gloss definition|Expression of disappointment or disgust.}} #: {{ux|en|Oh '''foo''' – the cake burnt!}} =====Synonyms===== * {{sense|expression of disgust}} {{l|en|darn}}, {{l|en|drat}} ===Etymology 4=== ====Alternative forms==== * {{l|en|foo'}} ====Noun==== {{en-noun}} # {{lb|en|slang}} {{eye dialect of|en|fool}} ===References=== * [[rfc:3092]], ''Etymology of "Foo"'', {{w|Internet Engineering Task Force}} (IETF) ===Anagrams=== * {{anagrams|en|a=foo|oof}} [[Category:English minced oaths]] [[Category:English placeholder terms]] ---- ==Middle English== ===Etymology 1=== From the oblique stem of {{inh|enm|ang|ġefāh}}. ====Noun==== {{enm-noun}} # {{alt form|enm|fo}} ===Etymology 2=== From {{inh|enm|ang|fā}}, variant of {{m|ang|fāh}}. ====Adjective==== {{enm-adj}} # {{alt form|enm|fo}} ====Adverb==== {{enm-adv}} # {{alt form|enm|fo}} ---- ==Tetum== ===Verb=== {{head|tet|verb}} # to [[stink]]
